quoteFirst: Still pressing on towards nightfall, we came in touch with an enemy flank patrol, and opened fire on them with rifles, Hotchkiss guns, and artillery. It was now very late at night, so we returned back to Dahra Barracks for food and water for the horses. It was
quoteLast: when we made down our beds and lay down for the night. When we had been in bed about half an hour, the order came for the 1st and 3rd Troops to saddle up at once, and I heard Mr Payne, the officer in charge, tell the troop sergeant that we were going out on the flank, on reconnaissance.
title: The Thirteenth Hussars in the Great War
author: Durand, H. Mortimer (Henry Mortimer), 1850-1924

quoteFirst: The battle of Shiloh, or Pittsburg Landing, was one of the most fiercely contested of the war. On the morning of April 6, 1862, the five divisions of McClernand, Prentiss, Hurlbut, W. H. L. Wallace, and Sherman, aggregated about thirty-two thousand men. We had no intrenchments of any sort, on the theory that as soon as Buell arrived we would march to Corinth to attack the enemy. The rebel army, commanded by General Albert Sidney Johnston, was, according to their own reports and admissions, forty-five thousand strong, had the momentum of attack, and beyond all question fought skillfully from early morning till
quoteLast: , when their commander-in-chief was killed by a Mini-ball in the calf of his leg, which penetrated the boot and severed the main artery. There was then a perceptible lull for a couple of hours, when the attack was renewed, but with much less vehemence, and continued up to dark. Early at night the division of Lew Wallace arrived from the other side of Snake Creek, not having fired a shot. A very small part of General Buell's army was on our side of the Tennessee River that evening, and their loss was trivial.
title: Project Gutenberg Edition of The Memoirs of Four Civil War Generals
author: Grant, Ulysses S. (Ulysses Simpson), 1822-1885; Logan, John Alexander, 1826-1886; Sheridan, Philip Henry, 1831-1888; Sherman, William T. (William Tecumseh), 1820-1891; Widger, David, 1932-2021? [Compiler]

quoteFirst: Still pressing on towards nightfall, we came in touch with an enemy flank patrol, and opened fire on them with rifles, Hotchkiss guns, and artillery. It was now very late at night, so we returned back to Dahra Barracks for food and water for the horses. It was
quoteLast: when we made down our beds and lay down for the night. When we had been in bed about half an hour, the order came for the 1st and 3rd Troops to saddle up at once, and I heard Mr Payne, the officer in charge, tell the troop sergeant that we were going out on the flank, on reconnaissance.
title: The Thirteenth Hussars in the Great War
author: Durand, H. Mortimer (Henry Mortimer), 1850-1924

quoteFirst: Immediately tongues seemed to be mechanically loosened and the conversation flowed freely, discussing the ride, horses, coming stiffness, and all the things that one has to talk about after two and a-half days in the saddle. On reaching the estancia
quoteLast: , none of us needed much bed, and throwing our things down on the grass outside, we soon were dreaming of alligators, broken bridges, swimming rivers, etc.
title: Argentina from a British Point of View, and Notes on Argentine Life
author: Ogilvie, Campbell Patrick [Compiler]

quoteFirst: It is a common mistake of mountaineers not to breakfast early enough and not to breakfast often enough. If it be desired to achieve a long expedition when there is not likely to be too much spare time, the wise man will eat something at least every two hours up to about 10 o’clock in the morning, supposing, for instance, he started
quoteLast: It is astonishing to notice how the full man gains upon the empty one on fatiguing snow slopes. We strode rapidly across the basin of snow called the Jägifirn and arrived at the foot of the gully.
title: Above the Snow Line: Mountaineering Sketches Between 1870 and 1880
author: Dent, C. T. (Clinton Thomas), 1850-1912; Whymper, Edward, 1840-1911 [Engraver]; Macquoid, Percy, -1925 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: Here no one could say where the 56th Division was, and I was directed to leave by a midnight train and to report to the R.T.O. at Abbéville. I got there
quoteLast: and was told to go back to Étaples by an 8 o'clock train that morning. I managed to get a few hours' sleep and breakfast at the Officers Club at Abbéville, and reached Étaples about midday on April 7. On April 9 I was told to proceed to St.
title: Q.6.a and Other places: Recollections of 1916, 1917 and 1918
author: Buckley, Francis, 1881-1949

quoteFirst: I joined them an hour later, and found one or two other visitors--of whom Glazounov was one. They had already had their supper, and I was afterwards told my brother had eaten macaroni and drunk, as usual, white wine and soda water. We went home
quoteLast: Peter Ilich was perfectly well and serene.
title: The Life & Letters of Peter Ilich Tchaikovsky
author: Chaikovskii, Modest, 1850-1916; Newmarch, Rosa, 1857-1940 [Translator]

title: Writing for Vaudeville
author: Page, Brett

quoteFirst: "You will note," he went on, "that the man on beat heard a shot at
quoteLast: ; that he met a tenant from the house who said that he had heard sounds of a struggle, a shot, and something like the falling of a body. The police found the flat locked, and after they broke in could find no one on the premises.
title: The Sheridan Road Mystery
author: Thorne, Paul; Thorne, Mabel

quoteFirst: Here no one could say where the 56th Division was, and I was directed to leave by a midnight train and to report to the R.T.O. at Abbéville. I got there
quoteLast: and was told to go back to Étaples by an 8 o'clock train that morning. I managed to get a few hours' sleep and breakfast at the Officers Club at Abbéville, and reached Étaples about midday on April 7. On April 9 I was told to proceed to St.
title: Q.6.a and Other places: Recollections of 1916, 1917 and 1918
author: Buckley, Francis, 1881-1949

quoteFirst: The sky remained overcast, and the wind cold. I was in and out like a jack-in-the-box all night.
quoteLast: there was a few minutes' slight drizzle, and my heart sank. At first streak of dawn ("sparrow-crack," in the vernacular) we were out, choked down some breakfast, then crossed into Braun's and drove Pardy's bullocks into a timber track in the scrub, cooping them up safely with a few bits of barb wire across the entrance. The morning was misty.
title:
From Chart House to Bush Hut
Being the Record of a Sailor's 7 Years in the Queensland Bush
author: Bryde, C. W.

quoteLast: on our first day in, a figure loomed up through a snow-storm from the back of the central trench and asked forlornly if there might be any mines hereabouts. We admitted there might be, or again there might not.
title: Punch, or the London Charivari, Vol. 150, March 15, 1916
author: Various; Seaman, Owen, 1861-1936 [Editor]

quoteFirst: They waited there in silence for five minutes, and once Hartley, with his back towards the house, struck a match under his sheltering coat, looked to see what time it was, and it was
title: The Quest: A Romance
author: Forman, Justus Miles, 1875-1915; Hatherell, William, 1855-1928 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: We reached the summit at 12.30 A.M., drenched through and through with perspiration. We set to and made sangars, and then lay down in biting cold at
quoteLast: , one blanket apiece. In spite of the cold I should have slept had it not been for a man alongside me who snored vigorously all night. We were lying on flat rocks--none too soft. Our commanding officer was up before dawn looking out for our friends, the Boers, opposing Buller, for we were now in rear of their right, and if they had waited till daylight we should have gone for them; but our friends the seven must have warned them, for they had retired during the night.
title:
South Africa and the Transvaal War, Vol. 6 (of 8)
From the Occupation of Pretoria to Mr. Kruger's Departure from South Africa, with a Summarised Account of the Guerilla War to March 1901
author: Creswicke, Louis

quoteFirst: Forty-eight hours after this night-chase, we had another, though with better success, as a prize rewarded me for my loss of rest. The chase commenced
quoteLast: , and it was half-past seven A. M., before we were near enough to heave the fugitive to, with a gun. She proved to be the _Jabez Snow_, of Buckport, Maine, last from Cardiff, with a cargo of coal, for Montevideo.
title: Memoirs of Service Afloat, During the War Between the States
author: Semmes, Raphael, 1809-1877

quoteLast: we were abreast of another beautiful glacier, a great river of ice slowly making its way from the eternal inland ice to the sea. The smooth and even appearance of all the glaciers, Mr. Peary told me, was due to the blanket of snow which covered them.
title: My Arctic journal: a year among ice-fields and Eskimos
author: Peary, Josephine Diebitsch, 1863-1955; Peary, Robert E. (Robert Edwin), 1856-1920 [Contributor]

quoteLast: we were abreast of another beautiful glacier, a great river of ice slowly making its way from the eternal inland ice to the sea. The smooth and even appearance of all the glaciers, Mr. Peary told me, was due to the blanket of snow which covered them.
title: My Arctic journal: a year among ice-fields and Eskimos
author: Peary, Josephine Diebitsch, 1863-1955; Peary, Robert E. (Robert Edwin), 1856-1920 [Contributor]

quoteFirst: The bombs gave us a bad moment or two. They did not kill any one, but threw up such clouds of dust that we were literally blinded; and then the main attack started at
quoteLast: on the right and developed all along the row of trenches. A lull occurred till about 3 a.m.
title: In the Line of Battle: Soldiers' Stories of the War
author: Wood, Walter, 1866-1961 [Editor]

quoteFirst: It was on June 21, 1916, that the third battle of Ypres started, our regiment being in the line at Kemmel Hill, and our 3rd Canadian division at Ypres. On the second of that month "Fritzie" made his drive for Ypres. The battle started
quoteLast: The Huns came over in massed formation, and very strong in number, almost six to one of "ours." All the boys in my battalion were sitting on top of the trench, looking on at the attack.
title:
What the "Boys" Did Over There
By "Themselves"
author: Fox, Henry L. (Henry Landell), 1872- [Editor]

quoteLast: on Wednesday morning," said he, "it being a dark, wet night, with the rain pouring down like water out of a bucket, and the thunder claps as near overhead, and as frequent, as ever I heard, I was on duty near St. Mark's Church just outside Regent's Park. There is a small bridge for foot passengers across the canal opposite and I crossed it on my way to the outer circle of the Park.
title: Mrs. Vanderstein's jewels
author: Bryce, Marion
